pageContext.claim: “They [coal] would not have lasted six months if crooked Hillary got elected. They would not have lasted for six months. It was gone. Now it's a vibrant industry again.”
pageContext.analysis: This is mostly baloney. The U.S. has added fewer than 2,000 coal mining jobs since Trump took office, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. That's a drop in the bucket when measured against the 125,000-job loss in this industry since its most recent peak in 1985, or the 36,000-job loss since 2012. U.S. coal consumption in 2018 was at its lowest level in 39 years, according to the Energy Information Administration. More coal-fired plants closed in Trump’s first two years in office than in the entirety of Obama’s first term. Indeed, EIA in 2019 forecast a 21 percent decline in coal production over the next 20 years.
